text: KELSEY ALPAIO: Coding is magic.

And if you're like
me, you probably

stare in awe at the
people who engineer

all of the amazing
digital experiences

that we're staring at pretty
much every single second
of the day.

Even this video you're
watching right now

had some sort of
coding involved.

But I don't really
know what it is.

In my head, it's kind of just
these people in a dark room,

typing as fast as they
can, creating the matrix.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

And they're hacking the
mainframe and the system.

That's pretty much like
all I think about when I
think of software engineering.

I can't help but
wonder what does it
like to be a full-time coder?

What is it like to be
a software engineer?

LINDSEY REDD: And that
feeling, that gratification

of figuring out how to do
something, or solving a bug,
or whatever, is like unmatched.

KELSEY ALPAIO:
That's Lindsay Reid.

She's a software
engineer that's worked

at some of the
coolest tech companies

out there, Slack,
Lyft, and now Stripe.

As a software engineer,
she's part of the magic
that makes these products work.

First question, does her
job actually look like--
[MUSIC PLAYING]
LINDSEY REDD: I mean, I do that.
Like, I don't hack.
But black screen, green tags--

I don't prefer those
particular colors.
You can change them.

But that is definitely
part of the job,
but it's like probably 50%.

A lot of the job is
very collaborative
and not solo work at all.

Usually, my day starts with
like looking through what
I have to do for the day.

So I know a lot
of software teams
use task-management tools.

My team, specifically,
uses Jira.
And we use a ticketing system.

And then coding, of course,
but you code, you test,
you deploy your code.

You monitor your code and
make sure things are working.

KELSEY ALPAIO: Do
people actually
grow up wanting to be coders?

Like, did Lindsey always
know that she wanted
to be a software engineer?
LINDSEY REDD: No, not at all.

I didn't even know what it
was until I was in college.

I wanted to be a doctor,
like in high school,
or a bio-mechanical engineer.
My dad's a doctor.

And my mom's a
chemical engineer.

And so something with STEM, I
knew was going to be my path.
I went to Stanford.

And Stanford is a huge
computer science school.

So a lot of my friends
were taking intro
to computer science courses.
I had never coded.

I just really didn't
know what it was.

But everyone was
having a great time

and seemed to find it
really interesting.

So around my sophomore
year I decided

to take a class in
computer science.

And my mentality was
if I like this class,
I'll take the next class.

And then after that,
if I like that class,
then I'll major in it.

And that's basically
what happened.

KELSEY ALPAIO: I love the
version of peer pressure

at Stanford, which is like, you
have to take a computer science
class.
LINDSEY REDD: Yeah.

Yeah, definitely not
what I was expecting.
But I'm glad it happened.

I definitely just
stumbled into it.

It's lucky I think that
I went to a school that
focuses so heavily on it.

KELSEY ALPAIO: What
were those classes like?

When you first started
doing it, was it

something that you were
scared of, or intimidated by,

or was it like
kind of accessible?
What did that feel like for you?

LINDSEY REDD: I enjoyed the
classes because a lot of it
is--

I mean, you're
actually coding, right?

And that is what I currently
do right now on the job.

And I liked that direct
application of skills,

like I am learning things
that I will eventually
use in my career.
So yeah, it was fun.

It was like, at first,
it's a lot of puzzles.

You code like a little
robot that navigates a maze.
Like, it's simple stuff.

I think my final project
in my first class

was building an extremely
basic, like Facebook.

KELSEY ALPAIO: OK, I need a
little bit of explanation.

What are the different types of
software engineers out there?

KELSEY ALPAIO: The
basics are front-end,

which is more like
web development

or like what you see on
your computer screen,

and then back-end, which is more
like servers, and algorithms,

and things like that
you don't see as a user,

but that help power
the front-end.

And there are people
who are full-stack who
do both of those things.

There is infrastructure
engineering,

which is a lot of
building out services,

like micro-services, or
servers, or monolithic servers,

or observability pipelines,
all kinds of things

that need to sit underneath
the back-end layer in order

for it to work, if
that makes any sense.

A lot of developer tooling
is considered infrastructure,

just things that kind of
keep the upper-layers layers
working, if that make sense.

KELSEY ALPAIO: No matter what
type of engineering you choose,

Lindsey says that when you're
ready to search for a job,

you should be ready for an
intense interview process, one
that takes a lot of studying.

LINDSEY REDD: Studying for
software engineering interviews

is a whole ordeal,
in and of itself.

And at the time, I didn't
really understand that.
And so I didn't study well.

And, I don't know,
luckily, I had some skills

under my belt that served
me in my interview.

But it made it a
lot difficult, just

because I was very
confused about how this was
going to translate into my job.

KELSEY ALPAIO: You
have to basically start

studying before you
even know if you've
got an interview lined up.
Is that right?
LINDSEY REDD: Yeah.

And I mean, a lot of
companies understand that that
is part of the process.

So recruiters are very--
in my experience, anyway--

flexible in giving
you like as much time
as you want really to study.

For my current job, I
remember asking my recruiter

if I could have four or
five weeks to study before I
actually did the interview.

And they were like, oh,
yeah, I totally get it.

But a lot of people,
once they decide, OK, I'm

going to switch jobs or
I need to go find a job,

they know like that
means like, I need
to start studying tomorrow.

KELSEY ALPAIO: So
you're coding in front
of the interviewee, like live?

LINDSEY REDD: In
most cases, I know

Lyft does an interview where
you get like an hour to code
a small project on your own.

The interviewer doesn't have
to be there, so you can focus.

But I think in all other
interviews that I've been in

and that I hear
my friends are in,

your coding in front
of someone or pair

programming with someone
during the interview.
It's a lot of pressure.

And it's interesting
because I mean
you do pair program on the job.

So interviews that involve
pair programming, I think,
are really great, honestly.

But the kind of just coding when
someone's watching and judging

your performance is not
typical of the job of,

a lot of it you're
just doing on your own.

KELSEY ALPAIO: So
it's also, I was

thinking about how software
engineering and the tech

industry, in general,
it's predominantly
white, predominantly male.

Would you mind
talking a little bit

about what it's like to kind of
navigate an industry like that?
LINDSEY REDD: Yeah.
It's hard.
It's definitely a struggle.

You definitely get people
who doubt your skills,

doubt your skill
set and undermine
your work, which sucks.
And it's hard.

And I think it's more work than
the white dude kind of software

engineer has to go
through to find a team

and find a company
that will work for you.

You know, what does diversity
look like at your company?

How does your company
think about or treat
diversity and inclusion?

Are there other
people at the company

who look like me who are
doing well and feel good?

That's definitely a
piece of my research.

And it's hard work,
in and of itself,

to kind of vet those things
and figure those things out.

But it's kind of
necessary in order for me

to be the best employee
or engineer that I can be.

KELSEY ALPAIO: OK,
let's talk about money.

What should I expect to get paid
in a software engineering role?

LINDSEY REDD: If you're
in one of the kind
of coastal locations--

San Francisco, New York, LA,
like some of these larger,
more established tech hubs--

out of college, if you
are not making $100,000,

at least, you're
probably being underpaid

or could at least find a
company that would pay you more.

I'm not sure what
that looks like.

If you're finding a job
in Atlanta, for example,

it might look very
different down there,
and I'm not familiar.

I would also say,
talk to your friends.

I think people don't talk about
how much they make enough,

which I think lends to a lot of
pay inequity in the industry.

It's what needs
to happen in order

to hold these companies
that, a lot of times

don't want to pay you
fairly, accountable.

KELSEY ALPAIO: Software
engineering is almost nothing
like I expected it to be.

It's not just people
typing away as fast
as they can in a dark room.
It's a lot more about teamwork.

It's a lot more
about collaboration
and communication.

If you're coming away
from this video thinking

that you want to pursue
software engineering,

it's good to know that it's
not magic, but it is hard work.

LINDSEY REDD: What
people are looking

for when you're an intern
on a team is your ability

to communicate, both verbal
and written communication,

and your ability
to problem solve,

know what kind of
questions do you

ask do, you make sure you
ask questions to solve

your problems, how fast are
you able to ramp up and learn

new technologies, new skills,
new languages quickly.

And then what kind of energy
do you bring to the team?

What is it like
working with you?

KELSEY ALPAIO:
Thanks for watching.
Do you have a career crush.

Tell us about them
in the comments

and we'll see if we can
talk to them for you.

Subscribe to our channel to
see more interviews with people
actually living the dream.
Bye.
